meta.article_title: May 23, 2011 - Pushing: Five out of Six Doesn't Cut It

may_23_2011_pushing_five_out_of_six_does.probleme: Deep pushes get attacked by stronger players
causes_communes: Push lacks one or more of the six key attributes: quick off the bounce, deep, low, heavy, angled, disguised placement

debutant: Make long pushes quick off the bounce and deep to reduce opponent’s preparation time.
Keep pushes low over the net with solid backspin to increase error rate.
intermediaire: Angle most pushes to the corners; occasionally go quick to the middle to force a forehand/backhand decision.
Disguise placement so direction (wide forehand or backhand) is decided at the last second.
avance: Combine all six attributes on the same push to challenge advanced attackers.

erreurs_a_eviter: Pushing safely inside corners instead of to angles

meta.article_title: April 11, 2011 - The Value of Down the Line

april_11_2011_the_value_of_down_the_line.diagnostic: Players and opponents expect crosscourt; down-the-line re-direction causes hesitation.
causes_communes: Habit from warm-ups focusing forehand-to-forehand and backhand-to-backhand
Preference for the larger crosscourt target

debutant: Occasionally direct attacks down the line to catch the opponent moving for crosscourt.
intermediaire: Mix patterns so opponent must cover both diagonals and down-the-line threats.
avance: Use down-the-line changes at decisive moments after conditioning opponent to expect crosscourt.

exercices_complementaires.description: Alternate forehand-to-backhand and backhand-to-forehand in warm-up to practice re-directing down the line; focus on timing and racket angle.

erreurs_a_eviter: Playing only crosscourt and becoming predictable

meta.article_title: September 12, 2011 - The Myth of Thinking Too Much

september_12_2011_the_myth_of_thinking_t.probleme: Overthinking during points leads to choking or hesitation
september_12_2011_the_myth_of_thinking_t.diagnostic: Attempting conscious control mid-rally instead of relying on trained subconscious responses.
causes_communes: Thinking during the point rather than between points and games
Insufficient pre-point tactical priming for the subconscious

debutant: Do tactical thinking between points and games; before service/receive, clear the mind.
Let the subconscious execute strokes during the rally.
intermediaire: Reinforce tactical cues repeatedly so the subconscious triggers correct actions automatically (e.g., loop deep serves to wide forehand).
avance: Systematically train responses against common spins and patterns so aiming, trajectory, and choices become habitual under pressure.

erreurs_a_eviter: Consciously trying to control stroke mechanics mid-point
Failing to think between points, leading to poor tactics

stepping_around_the_backhand_corner.probleme: Inability to use the forehand from the backhand corner
stepping_around_the_backhand_corner.diagnostic: Player moves too soon, misreads depth, or lacks proper step-around footwork and shot timing.
causes_communes: Leaving neutral stance and committing before opponent commits
Poor judgment of depth on pushes and blocks
Inefficient footwork sequence and delayed swing

debutant: Use neutral stance (for righties: left foot slightly forward, knees bent, weight on inside balls of feet).
Wait until the opponent commits before stepping around; anticipate pushes to the backhand more often.
intermediaire: Footwork sequence: short step left with left foot, then pull/push off left to jump/step so right foot moves left; rotate shoulders so they are at least parallel to end line; weight onto right foot; step into shot with left.
Begin forward swing as right foot lands; keep backswing and forward swing as one continuous motion.
avance: Force weak returns to the backhand via placement (e.g., quick to middle/elbow) or speed/spin variation; if short depth, step around to flip instead of loop.
Prepare for last-second down-the-line counters and recover if the opponent redirects.

erreurs_a_eviter: Taking a backswing, pausing, then swinging (non-continuous motion)
Starting swing too late after stepping around
Standing in a non-neutral stance that cramps the shot

are_you_backhand_oriented.probleme: Backhand orientation crowding out forehand development
are_you_backhand_oriented.diagnostic: Ready position covers most of table with backhand; forehand cannot rotate and generate power.
causes_communes: Feet parallel in middle; elbow position biases backhand coverage
Short-term success with backhand prevents forehand growth

debutant: Adopt healthy ready position (for righties: left foot slightly forward, slight clockwise rotation, knees bent, weight on inside balls of feet).
intermediaire: Persist through discomfort as table ‘shifts’ relative to stance; keep new foot position to enable forehand swing and better backhand posture.
avance: Work with a coach to rebuild forehand technique from the improved stance and to resist reverting to backhand-dominant posture.

erreurs_a_eviter: Reverting to parallel-feet stance that favors backhand
Refusing short-term discomfort that blocks long-term forehand development

meta.article_title: February 28, 2011 - A Forehand Stance While Blocking

february_28_2011_a_forehand_stance_while.probleme: Blocking from a backhand stance limits forehand options
february_28_2011_a_forehand_stance_while.diagnostic: Backhand stance weakens ability to block/smash/counterloop on forehand and to step around.
causes_communes: Habitual backhand stance when receiving fast balls
Poor readiness to transition to forehand attack

debutant: Experiment with a slight forehand stance while blocking to keep both wings available.
intermediaire: Use forehand stance to enable quick step-around on weak balls and to counterloop or smash on forehand.
avance: In matches, adopt forehand stance to block backhands patiently until a forehand ball appears, then finish decisively.

erreurs_a_eviter: Locking into a backhand-only stance during rallies

meta.article_title: June 20, 2011 - Are You a Tree or a Squirrel?

june_20_2011_are_you_a_tree_or_a_squirre.diagnostic: Player waits to see if movement is needed instead of being ready to move on every shot.
causes_communes: Standing rooted without knee flex or bounce
Deciding whether to move instead of where to move

debutant: Stay in motion between shots: flex knees and do a small bounce to prime movement.
Expect to move on every ball; decide where to move, not whether.
intermediaire: Use random-placement drills to train first-step reactions without anticipation.
avance: Ensure first move is always correct and light, building automatic reaction-based footwork.

exercices_complementaires.description: Partner blocks or feeds multiball randomly across the table; react without anticipating; focus on instant first step and continuous small bounce.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; bucket of balls (for multiball optional)

erreurs_a_eviter: Waiting flat-footed and reaching awkwardly for the ball

meta.article_title: September 19, 2011 - Balance Leads to Feet-first Footwork

september_19_2011_balance_leads_to_feet_.probleme: Reaching with the playing arm before moving feet
september_19_2011_balance_leads_to_feet_.diagnostic: Arm-first movement slows positioning, produces awkward contact, and throws player off balance onto the lead foot.
causes_communes: Weight shifting before moving, preventing quick first step

debutant: Keep weight centered between feet while moving; avoid reaching before stepping.
intermediaire: Move the correct foot first (right to move right, left to move left) and glide into position before any weight shift.
Focus on balance as the cue that naturally triggers feet-first movement.
avance: Use balance-focused practice to eliminate arm-first habits so first step becomes automatic and efficient.

erreurs_a_eviter: Reaching for the ball with arm before feet
Placing weight on the lead foot before initiating movement
